text: WINDS HOWL. Rain drives horizontal. The sea surges up,  nearly to the flight deck of the Aircraft Carrier USS Kit Hawk. The carrier plunges, driving its bow into a wall of grey water. The deck pitches forward and back, rolls left right, and yaws in a corkscrew motion. The entire 93,000 behemoth rises and falls in the TYPHOON-DRIVEN SWELL.

head_text.subj: SOMETHING DROPS DOWN OUT OF THE NIGHT

text: A ROAR. Silver wings flash by, a cockpit, fiery jet  exhausts. A forty ton monster drops at 120 knots into an the size of a tennis court in a CONTROLLED CRASH.

2A.  A SHOWER OF SPARKS, A SCREECH OF RUBBER AND METAL as the gear hits the deck. The hook catches the 3 wire and t F-14 TOMCAT is slammed to a halt. It's the scariest thing you've ever seen, the most dangerous maneuver in aviation just another day at the office for a Naval Aviator.
Leans almost horizontal into the winds. He holds the pick controlling the landing lights and speaks into a mike. Hi calm, professional commands belie the extreme conditions.

head_text.subj: ANOTHER TOMCAT FLIES OVER THE RAMP

text: It slams in. The pilot hits full power, catches the wire, to a stop, cuts his engines.
Lots of scopes and electronic gear. The CARRIER CONTROL A OFFICER (CCA) watches a blip on radar, reaches for his mi

We float like gods, above the storm, above the cloud cove looking down. From overhead, a probe slides into frame, t a graceful nose. The cockpit sides by, Pilot, then Radar  Intercept Officer (RIO) barely illuminated by the orange of their instruments. The fuselage gracefully swells to t enormous air intakes, then variable angle wings, swept ba for high speed flight. Twin tailbooms cant outward,  horizontal stabilizers make constant adjustments. Enormou twin jet exhaust ports glow red in the moonlight.

We become aware of WIND WHISTLE, JET ENGINE SOUNDS, RADIO STATIC. The pilot, COUGAR, is calm, steady. The Radar  Intercept Officer in the backseat, GOOSE, is a wildman,  always an edge of humor in his voice. A UHF transmission  breaks in..

Come in on the cockpit with stenciled name and call signs EVAN MITCHELL is the pilot, MAVERICK. In flight suit and mask, we can only see his eyes. they are confident. In hi mid-twenties, he is lean, hard, athletic...the archetype pilot. His rear-seater is LTJG. WALTER MERLIN; WIZARD.
Maverick peels off to right, to high cover position; 5 o'

HEADS UP DISPLAY (HUD) glows dimly on the windscreen. Dir in front of the stick, two CRT screens display data. The screen shows a radar sweep. Wedged between the instrument snapshot of a pretty young woman with a 2 month-old baby.

Maverick sees a SECOND MiG drop from above onto Cougar's

He is closing on the first MiG when a shocking BLIPBLIPBL tone breaks into their headsets.
I've got a six strobe.  I think  he's locked on us.
It's a MiG 21. They don't have  radar missiles!
Cougar swings mad gyrations, cutting back and forth acros front MiG's tailpipe, trying to break the lock-on. The TO more insistant.
Lordy!  Eyeball to Asshole. Hope nobody burps!
I'LL LOCK ON THEM, COUGAR. (to himself)   Gotcha covered, don't nobody move.
ROGER, COUGAR. (to himself and his RIO)  Okay boys, pull out with your hands up  and nobody'll get hurt.
Up front, Cougar checks his gunsight...He gets I.R. lock.
We're locked on MiG ONE. Why  doesn't he disengage?
These guys are getting on my  nerves.
But Cougar presses forward, and MiG TWO stays on his tail

head_text.subj: COUGAR, BREAK LEFT. TRY A HIGH G

text: Anger gives way to discipline. Cougar's Tomcat breaks lef dives into dense cloud. MiG TWO still follows.
He rolls over into wild evasive maneuvers, finally breaks

Breaks out of cloud, looks around, startled.  There is no no F-14. He scans the sky frantically, while rolling the  aircraft. ...Suddenly, he feels a presence. He looks stra and behind him. A few feet away, a TOMCAT slides into pos canopy to canopy, an incredible feat of flying. Maverick Wizard stare at him. Maverick slides even closer, canopie touching. The MiG pilot acknowledges them with a weak wav Maverick stares for a moment, then flips him the bird.
The MiG pushes negative G, hard down and away. He heads f deck.
Ah, the thrill of victory and the  agony of defeat.
Speaking of feet, fuel's down to  4.0.  We're gonna get them wet  unless we find a Sonoco station.

text: Stands the on plunging deck, peering into the roaring nig
This is crazy. How the hell we  supposed to land on something we  can't even see!
Hey, if it was easy, everybody  would want to come up here and do  it..... Instead of just us.
Call the ball?  I don't see the  ship!
BLASTS slam the airframe. Rain tattoos the canopy. A gust the Tomcat, he straightens it, A gust flips it again.
The Carrier lights appear and disappear through the storm
A walk in the park, Mustang. You  with me, cat man?...Cougar...you  with me?
Goose is thrown about as the wing dips, straightens, dips
Help me with this one, I'm really  screwed up.
Bring it left. Bring it left,  You're high.
Can't you feel it? I'm hanging in  my straps!
You're not. We're level. Look at  the instruments, we're okay!
They must be broken. I'm hanging in  my straps! We're inverted!
We're not! Trust me! We're okay.
He hears Cougar's chatter over the air.

head_text.subj: WELL, WE CAN'T STAY UP HERE EITHER.

text: Maverick's plane settles in over the ramp, suddenly, BLAS IT'S AFTERBURNERS...it ROARS over the deck without touchi off into the night. The LSO is shocked into comment.
What makes you think we can get  back in?  We don't have the fuel  for this. MAVERICK
He's nine o'clock high. We're two  thousand pounds low!
Maverick's plane pulls up behind Cougar's. Cougar's plane suddenly flips over, flying inverted.
Maverick pulls up off the wing of the inverted aircraft. voice is calmness itself.

COUGAR, THIS IS MAVERICK. HALF ROLL

We're on vapor, Cougar, you got to  put it down.
It's crazy, man. Instruments are  crazy. We're gonna have to eject.

THING UPSIDE DOWN. AND I LIVE. I'LL

All eyes are on what they can see of the approach of the planes. Maverick drops him off at the pattern and circles LSO watches the approach. The Tomcat drops a wing, straig drops the wing, straightens ... the approach of a pilot  experiencing vertigo as Cougar tries to satisfy his inner
A wind shear just off the ramp drives the plane suddenly

AFTERBURNERS BLAST, but the Tomcat horrifyingly settles t toward the deck. The deck crew watches in terror as the p wallows in toward them. The LSO'S turn, take a few steps throw themselves off the flight deck.
They sail into the night toward the surging seas a hundre below, then are caught in safety nets hung off the side.

Settles, settles, standing on it's engines, trying to arr it's downward momentum. The hook raises sparks as it skid the deck... The plane stops falling and hangs for a momen to blast back up, when the hook catches the last wire.. T snags it, plucking 45,000 pounds of fuel, metal and men o the air and slamming it all to the deck. WHAMMMM! Right w flies up the deck and over the side...the gear collapses. plane SCREECHES sideways. The crew watches helplessly as slams into it and comes to rest in cloud of fuel vapor an
The LSO runs up, shouting into the mike.

Crash crew leaps into action. The fire crew is there. The the Silver Suit jumps up on the wing and crawls to the co The figures inside are not moving. He hits the canopy rel The canopy pops open. Silver suit grabs at the rear seat release. He screams through his suit's aluminized cloth..
Goose, can you hear me?  Goose!
Nothing for a moment. He's dead! Then the RIO'S helmet  moves...His head turns. He tears the mask away from his f looks up at Silver Suit. His head clears.
Silver suit is stunned for a moment. He straightens up, h inclines quizzically. Then it hits him.
You will put it up front, with the Porsches?
He grabs him under the armpits, drags him out of the plan
Hey...easy...Take it easy... I'm a veteran!
Goose grabs a passing crewman by the arm.
Can you check under the hood. I  thought I heard a funny noise.

Other crewmembers help Cougar out. He seems stunned, but reacts to his fear with frantic one-liners. He grabs a cr member's radio, as Silver Suit helps him away and looks t figures of the Admiral and the Air Boss far up on the bri He waves to them, does his best impression...Desi Arnaz.
A moment of disbelief... Then hysterical, tension relievi laughter.
Goose spots Cougar being helped out. He pulls away, reach into the cockpit and grabs Cougar's snapshot of wife and They lead Goose away as firemen blast the aircraft with f
Is it extra for the hot wax?
A TILLIE, a four wheel mobile crane, slams up to the plan slings its lifting harness. Goose turns to Silver Suit.
It's Goose. He's alright. Bring it  left...You're settling.  IS THE
Wizard does a quick sign of the cross, reaches down, grab balls...as...
The TOMCAT slams onto the deck, clearing the wreckage by

Watch as they bring a shaken Cougar past. Goose, eyes wil waves at Maverick and Wizard, rolling up. They flame out VVOOOMMMMM! They sit there, immobile, waiting for a tow, numb.  Goose does his "stewardess".

On behalf of your Captain and your  crew, I want to thank you for  flying VF101. And next time your  plans include the middle of the  goddamn ocean in the dead of  frigging night, I hope you'll think  of Naval Aviation.
The surgeon looks into Goose's eyes.
(wobbling off) Never mind my head, check my  shorts!
Cougar lies alone in the dimness, staring at the overhead

The usual CLANGS, WHISTLES, ENGINES of Navy life sound FO ECHOING through the dim, deserted passage. From the dista single figure passes in and out of the glow of the overhe lights. Cougar comes closer, hobbling unsteadily.
He reaches a door, pulls himself erect and knocks on the
The skipper works at his desk, responds without looking u
He looks up. Cougar stands in the doorway, a strange, daz on his face.
Cougar, what is it? You should be  in sick bay. What are you doing?
He walks over to the skipper's desk. His eyes are glazed, his jaw is firm.
Thinking of my wife and kid.
A determined movement. Hand to chest.
Something metal hits it, skids across the polished surfac clangs up against the coffee mug: gold wings.
Cougar comes out of Stinger's room, bumps into Goose, and Maverick. He turns the other way.
He stops, turns to them. There is nothing to say. Goose h him his snapshot. Cougar looks at his wife and kid for a then looks up at them. He turns away.
Cougar?                STINGER (O.S.) Maverick, Goose...Come in here.
Maverick appears, followed by Goose. They stand at  attention.
The Skipper says nothing. Maverick sees the wings on the  desk. He enters, walks over, stares down at them. He pick them up.
Don't worry. I'll talk to him.
I talked a man back once. Three  months later, we lost him. It's his  decision. Only he knows.
He's the best you have. He's going  Top Gun!
Was going. (Turns to Maverick.) Now  you are.
Maverick stares at the wings, lost in conflicting emotion
Well, he's going (indicating Goose)  and he needs someone to fly the  plane.
I didn't do it, he did it himself.  Something about a wife and kid. The  fact is, he's lost it. He knows it.  I know it. You were up there, you  know it, too. GOOSE
Give him a break, Skipper. It was  raining snakes up there. He'll be  alright, soon as all the gorillas go  home...
The Skipper stares at Goose, non-plussed for a moment.

I know some RIOS are a little  wiggy...but you abuse the  priviledge! I don't believe I'm  going to have to put the two of you  in the same cockpit...but there it  is! It may be good for the Navy. It  might be good for you, but most of  all, it's good for me. It'll get  you out of my sight.
But, Skipper, Cougar's been picked  for Top Gun...He's the best of the  best!
Well, you'll just have to make do  with him (indicates Maverick).
He's a hell of a flyer. In fact,  he's so damn good he might have  been picked for Top Gun himself.  Except for one thing. (SCREAMS) He  just can't seem to follow orders!
Stinger moves slightly, to stand now, directly in front o Maverick and speak eye to eye at four inches.

You just did an incredibly brave thing!  What you should have done was land your  plane. You don't own that plane, the  taxpayers do. I should ream you out for  it. But it just doesn't work with you.  You're a hell of a flyer. You are maybe  ...too good. You never really stepped in  it yet. So this is your chance. I'm  gonna send you up against the best. They  are better than you. Maybe they'll knock  that shine off your eagle and you'll  see, finally, where discipline and  teamwork fit it.  Maverick hasn't really heard anything but TOPGUN. He snap of it.
That is all. Tell me about the MiG  some other time...
He snaps off a salute and does an about face.
He looks down at the wings in his hands, slowing walks ov places them gently on the Skipper's desk.

Maverick and Goose push through a gauntlet of aircrews. T have become notorious. Guys grab at them...questions...th MiGs?..What happened up there? How close did they get? Wh the MiGs do? One word is heard over and over..."TopGun". left behind in the crowd. Maverick pushes through. He wal fast...faster. Up ladders, around turns, down ladders, th passageways. Faster. He breaks into a trot, then a canter squeezing past enlisted men, parts lockers, then he break run...

A hatch slams open on the side of the Carrier. He's out o catwalk, instantly soaked, running on rain slicked stairs cantilevered high over the breaking seas. He plunges forw the bow of the ship, stands on the very peak. He is yelli something. He stands there as the bow plunges terrifyingl the trough. The water rises like a green mountain, up, up break just a few feet below him, showering him with spray noise is incredible.
Come around on his face. It is maddened. He raises his fi punches the night.
The foaming slope of the wave rushes up, changing color a

A big bike, a real big bike, a turbo...rockets across the desert. Fast. Real fast. Aviator shades low above the han --Maverick. Goose hangs on in back. It cranks faster, pul closer...ENGINE SCREAMING. It cranks up a notch, it's goi
explode. It can't go faster, but it does. It SCREAMS HIGH ROARS under, by and away, leaving dust...
Silence. Just the HISS AND POP OF METAL COOLING. Maverick on it, staring out past us. Goose looks over Maverick's s
We see why. Feet come into the frame. Then the uniform:  California Highway Patrol.

40A.  ANGLE ON MAVERICK. CHP enters the frame, the usual  hypercivil arrogance tinged with awed disbelief. The usua questions are spaced for effect as if he might be talking other form of life. Maverick is off the bike, standing at attention. Goose follows more slowly.
Son. Do you know why I stopped you?
Maverick has some good idea how to deal with authority.
The CHP adjusts his own aviator shades. CHP
(more than sincere) Sir. You are going to give me a  warning, Sir!
CHP - A touch of a smile, quickly surpressed.
Maverick hands them over with his Navy ID. CHP scans them hesitates a moment over the last, looks up with a touch m respect.
Lieutenant, do you know how fast   you were going?
Sir. I was going Mach point one  five.
One SIXTH the speed of sound!
(a guess) Lieutenant... What do you...   usually fly?
A long pause. Respect in the cop's eyes. He taps the Navy the handlebars...staring at this sincere young man.
Lieutenant... Is there... a Russian attack?
No sir! But you have to be ready.
The cop nods and stares at him.

The bike is BLURPING... barely going fast enough to stay  upright. Maverick cool in shades and campaign cap dorks p hanger with the sign: FIGHTERTOWN, USA. He pulls ahead. I of him, escorting with flashers...the CHP. They pull up a gate. Maverick and Goose salute the guard, hands over the The CHP gets out of his car, leans against the door.
Outside of this gate... I...am Top Gun.

He salutes. The CHP returns a snappy one. He gets back in car and turns away. Maverick receives his ID and clearanc passes through, a couple of pilots in flight suits (ICE A HOLLYWOOD) stare at him. The taller, dark, cool one speak dry voice, meant to be overheard.
Uh oh, police escort. This one must  be a real killer.
The second pilot grins big at them. Maverick turns slight stares over his shades at them as he passes. Goose grins challenge.
The Doors on the soundtrack.  Jets swoop, missiles fire, explodes. Gun camera views of MiGs, SAMS, flak, bombing r

During the Korean War, the Navy kill  ratio was twelve-to-one. We shot down  twelve of their jets for every one of  ours. In Vietnam, this ratio fell to  three-to-one. Our pilots depended on  missles. They lost their dogfighting  skills.
F-14's fighting with F-5's. Music becomes current.

Top Gun was created to teach ACM. Air  Combat Maneuvering...Dogfighting.  Richthofen, Guynemer, Rickenbacker,  Galland, Rudel, Bong would envy us. We  do just what they did, but we do it  beyond the speed of sound.
VIPER - A tough-looking, confident leader in a blue fligh stands before a video-tape monitor. Behind him, on the mo the dogfighting continues.
By the end of Vietnam we upped our  kill ratio to thirteen to one.
He turns on the lights. We see his audience in F.G.
You're here 'cause you're the top  one per cent of all naval aviators.
Sixteen young men - eight flight crews - sit at attention are trim, fit and confident - high school heroes, college
You're the elite, the best of the  best. We're gonna make you better,  because you're job is damned  important.
The camera moves among them. Hold on one of the men; the greeted Maverick at the gate, Ice.
With the tensions in the world today, the potential for c tation is greater than ever, and  carrier pilots will be the first  ones there. Air combat excellence  is vital.

Ice is not looking at the speaker, but, rather, in our  direction. HOLLYWOOD, a blond, good-looking pilot, whispe something to him, and gestures. Ice is getting the lowdow someone. The camera moves and we see who that someone is, Maverick enters the frame.
...Someone once asked me if  training men for air combat made  the world less safe--flying loaded  guns... an accidental confrontation  and so forth...
Maverick feels the stare of the other man and glances in direction. Their eyes meet. Ice smiles coldly.

My answer is: the dangerous thing  is being unprepared. You want  trouble, that's what you get when  things don't work out, when you  can't do what you say you can. When  you don't know what you can do. And  when your opponents aren't sure  either. We are not policy. We don't  make policy. Elected officials  ...civilians, do that. We are the  instrument of policy. The tip of  the spear. So we had best be sharp.

Maverick has turned to look at Ice. Ice glances back in h direction. Maverick looks at the back of the room where g blue flight suits stand. They are the instructors. They l relaxed, poised, mean.  Goose is looking up front...Where has stopped. Goose nudges Maverick.
Nothing...That's McGown...that's  Singer, isn't it? GOOSE
Turn around, pay attention. What  are you doing?
(musing to himself) ...Just wondering...(turns back)  ...who is the best.
He's shocked to find Viper staring right at him, with a k grin on his face. He's feels caught like a naughty school

Really...    (smiles) Ya know. We'd like to know who's  best too. That's why we've got that  plaque on the wall... with the Top  Top Gun crew from each class. You  think maybe your name's gonna be on  it?
Maverick knows he's in trouble, considers the social  alternatives, then tells him the truth.
A couple of ooo's and aahh's from the guys. The instructo stare the challenge at him. He slides lower in his seat.
Considering the company you're in,  that's a pretty arrogant attitude.

I like that in a fighter pilot.   (couple of laughs from the guys)  It's okay to be confident. You have  to think you're King Kong to want  to try to land on carriers. Just  keep in mind the other component of  success...teamwork.
Viper gathers his notes, the lecture is over.
Viper turns back for one more thought.

Gentlemen, this is about combat.  Remember, there are no points for  second place. Dismissed. Viper walks out. Maverick finds Goose looking at him,  quizzically. Others mill around the plaque.  A big, frien of a RIO speaks.
It's not the plaque. The winner can  get assigned here as instructor. He  gets to fight every day.
They move closer to examine the names on the plaque.
Fast cars in the driveway, fast music blares into the  night. It's Wednesday; Animal Night. Maverick, Goose  Hollywood and Wolfman walk to the entrance.

Loud music, low ceiling, plaques of the squadrons line th walls. A dancer gyrates on stage, largely ignored by pilo talking with their hands. Every pretty girl in San Diego  seems to be here. It's a noisy, rowdy place--a "steam  releaser" for people under pressure. Nevertheless, there a control to it all, there are none of the usual bar type just pilots and Naval Officers.
The Ghost Riders enter. The place is on fire:  a mob of  dancers, flashing lights, blaring HARD ROCK MUSIC. Beer  flows. Pilots talk flying and hustle girls.
NEARBY - AN A7 pilot stands by the bar. He knows Goose an speaks loudly for his benefit..
You know the Fighter Pilots motto?  It's better to be dead than to look  bad.
They grin broadly. Goose replies as they brush past.
I don't know, Frank, anybody gets  off on bombing the shit out of dirt  has got to be queer.

Goose exchanges friendly punches with the attack pilots.  Maverick's introductions and friendly barbs are drowned b music. Maverick is a bit reserved. He doesn't move among crowd as naturally as Goose does. Hollywood and Wolfman d
away, searching for quarry. Goose orders beer. He nods to TALL YOUNG MAN across the room.
Keller, Black Lion Squadron. I knew  him at Pensacola. He's damn good.
Is there anybody in the Navy you  don't know?
Gotta keep track of the  competition.
Goose suddenly reaches out and grabs a guy moving past.
Slider -- they let you into Top  Gun? If you're among the best in  the Navy, I tremble for the  security of this country.
Why Goose, whose butt did you kiss  to get here?
The list is long, but  distinguished.
Smiles good-naturedly, shakes hands with Mav.
You think you can stay up with us.
I think, yeah, we'll show you a  thing or two.
This is Evan Mitchell, he steers  the thing.
So I heard. Steers it pretty close.  Sorry to hear about Cougar. He was  a good man.
Suddenly, behind them, a flame shoots up. Someone ducks h and swallows it. The pilot sets an empty glass on the bar

Flaming Hooker. Sort of an  institution around here. Or maybe  this is the institution, I forget  which. It's the house drink. It'll  warm the cockles of your heart ...  and other things depending on where  you spill it.
He motions to the barmaid and she moves over, sets them u GOOSE holds a demitasse glass. The barmaid pours Drambuie look at Goose apprehensively. Goose looks at nearby flyer Camo fatigues. GOOSE
You can't show fear in front of  Marines...They're like Doberman's  they'll go for your throat, it's  instinctive.
He takes out match and lights it. Maverick holds his arm.
He downs it all in one gulp, slaps the glass on the bar, aflame. He stands there, blinking.
Could use a dash more jet fuel.

The others are duly impressed. Maverick's gaze falls on I watching from the end of the bar - Slider takes one, Mave takes one too, downs it in a gulp. Sundown, taking up the challenge, motions for one. The barmaid pours it.
Careful, don't make an ash of  yourself...

He tries to drink the flaming concoction. He tries to go sip, but it's too close to his face, he tries to tilt the away, but that doesn't work. Finally he goes for the gulp burns his lip and misses.  He sets his hair on fire. It g in a WHOOOSH!!
He throws a beer in Sundown's face, quenching the fire. S blinks through the beer.
You guys are not only crazy, you're  dangerous!
Ice comes up from the end of the bar. He motions the Barm another; it comes. Goose lights it. He gulps it down, coo hell. ICE
He walks away. Slider goes after him.
No shit! That why they call him Ice?
Nope. It's the way he flies - Ice cold.  No mistakes. Wears you down. After  enough time, you just get bored and  frustrated, you do something stupid, and  he's got you.
Maverick moves in Ice's direction. He passes Wolfman danc with a girl with bright purple fingernails.
Why do you all have such funny  names?
You gotta have a call sign that's  just your own...never changes...you  have to recognize it immediately.  Then, if someone shouts "Wolf,  break left!"..you react right away.
Why do they call you Wolf?
Goose comes up with his arm around a girl.
Hey Mav, this is Sally. She doesn't  believe a word I say. Tell her I'm  married, will you?
Yeah, he's married--but then again,  he,s not dead.
Sally laughs and tries to pull Goose back toward the danc floor. Something in Maverick's eyes makes him hang back w partner.
Could I get a call sign?
Well, I don't know. That depends.
Well, it doesn't just happen, you  gotta do something famous.

Maverick smiles at this, but seems on edge... He watches pretty girls enter and eye the pilots in their flight sui turns and walks up to Ice, who sits, drinking with Slider Maverick walks over to him. Ice notices Slider's attentio to Maverick. He turns and grins at him.
I think I can work it out on my  own.
You like to work alone. I've heard  that about you.
I've heard of you, too. You were in  124 with Bargamian.
And you were with Cougar. He was my  roommate in flight school.
You must have soloed under a lucky  star. First the MiG, then you slide  into Cougar's place.
It's not Cougar's place. It's ours.
What do you think it was? Was it  that MiG contact that did it?
We're here because we're the best  flyers in the wing. Not because of  some MiG encounter.
What luck! Guys fly their whole  career without seeing a MiG up  close...You're famous.

Something in the way he says it. It's not quite a joke, m insult. Maverick's about to take the whole conversation t when something...someone catches his eye. She catches qui eyes in this room. She is very pretty and she's walking i arm of a Commander. Maverick turns back, but the moment h passed. Ice dismisses him with a nod and weak smile. Goos him away.
What do these guys think, I made  Cougar quit?
Pay no attention to it. They're  just trying to rattle you. It's all  psychological. Sit down..and drink.
He deposits Maverick at a chair by a table where other pi cluster watching and listening to Bugs shoot down his wri Maverick broods... BUGS

We were just really diving down and by  then we were right over downtown  Haiphong.  It was some great shit. Jack  says, "What are you doing?" "What, what  am I doing, Jack?" He says, "What are  you doing?" I said, "I'm rolling in,  Jack." "Bugs, we're at thirty-two  hundred feet. Oh shit, we were like  zooom... So we scraped down at hundred  feet right over--downtown Hanoi!  Oh  shit, goddamn it! And blowing down the  river. And so once we were there we let  down to about fifty feet just going down  the river and Jack says... "Bugs...  don't ever do that again!" "Okay, right,  Jack, I'll never do that again!"
Maverick pays little or no attention. He broods and drink Suddenly, Hollywood nudges him, he turns.
They turn. Long legs, great ass, beautiful.
Her six is a ten! Uh oh, a turn to  engage.
Maverick sees a stranger, and somehow he knows, he knows then.  Wolfman turns, sees her walking too.
Nine thirty. Bogey?  You presume  that hostile?
Well, we should contact and check  it out.

She has turned toward them. She passes by. They start to move for her. But just then she finds her date at the bar distinguished man with Captain's stripes. Their smiles fr they slide back in their chairs. Maverick can't stop look her...After a while, the intensity of his gaze draws her  attention. She feels him. She is nodding and smiling to h but her eyes scan the room like radar. A warning tone goe his brain dolu dolu dolu as they lock on him. He feels th thrill of excitement and fear you get when you know you'r targeted in someone's scope. Her eyes hold on him for a l moment...long enough, and then sweep by the rest of the r turns her attention back to the Captain and laughs at som he says.
Over in a corner, Goose chats up a couple of San Diego gi
The family unit -- that's the most  important thing. It's the only  thing you can count on. I'm married  --did I tell you that?
Four times. We don't believe you.
I've been married since I was  eighteen. Why don't you believe me?
You're not even wearing a ring.
(big smile) I take it off when I'm chasing  women. It's the only honorable  thing to do.

He's half listening to Bugs rattle on.  His eyes are draw to the woman. He tries not to stare. She seems to know a people in the club. He looks away. Hollywood is chatting girl with a sincerity that cannot be taught. His line is polished as his appearance.
You don't think about death up  there, but you think a lot about  the danger. One mistake and you're  a smoking hole in the ground.
I never knew it was so dangerous. HOLLYWOOD
Oh yeah, it makes everything down  here more meaningful. You feel a  certain intensity of life, and you  want to grab onto every moment.

Maverick looks up at the bar again. A shock. She (Charlie staring right at him, intensely, as her date whispers som in her ear. She notices him, staring back, quickly looks embarrassed. She says something to the man. He nods and t away as someone else grabs his attention. The woman, now look this way for anything. She picks up her purse from t and walks through the crowd and out of the room. Impulsiv Maverick's up, he follows.
He breaks out, looks around, doesn't see her. Someone dis around a corner. He moves after.
CORNER - A door slams shut. Impulsively, before he realiz he is doing, he's through it.

A feminine GASP!  He should have looked at the sign on th The realization of where he is hits him too late. She is by the mirror, with her make-up out, looking back at him. not quite sure what to do. A hasty retreat would be appro if embarrassing. Ah, what the hell, he is a fighter pilot just walks right over to her...no idea what he will say. got her lipstick out, twisting it. She looks over at him amused smile.
She leans over the sink, puts on lipstick, sees his eyes her.
Anything I can do to help, Lieutenant?
She laughs. He is sort of attractive, but there are other in the room, she doesn't want to be too encouraging...She not to grin at his embarrassment.
Uhhh...Anything I can do for you? She laughs again, doesn't know what it is...could be chem but she's instinctively attracted.
Yeah. Hold this. It might be safer.
She hands him a makeup mirror. Starts redoing her lipstic just stares at her...She looks up at him, than back to he warpaint. Finally, when it comes, it is cool and amused.
Now I know why all the girls come  here. They know how horny you guys  get. But this...is ridiculous.
Mock anger. She's toying with him.
Well, it is. It is that, too.
That's a big comfort to me.
Save you from a big mistake with  that other guy.
And on to a bigger one with you?
Was there ever a girl who didn't  like fighter pilots?
She laughs again, shakes her head...another cowboy! She g takes the compact out of his hands, snaps it closed.
I'm really flattered, Lieutenant,  but I don't go out with pilots. MAVERICK
Then what are you doing here?
Three pretty blondes enter and look at Maverick quizzical not without interest.
I think the question is...what are  you?
She tries to keep a straight face as she walks out of the
The other girls look at him expectantly.  A beat.  He jus stands there, then realizes he's holding her lipstick.
Hi. I'm here to talk about a new  concept in cosmetics...

47A.  WOXOF BAR. She returns, spots the Captain, motionin her.  Maverick enters, goes to the other end of the bar. orders a drink. It comes. He drinks it, pays for it, move toward the door. Someone backs into his path, he moves qu and bumps into someone else; her.
My fault. Should have watched where I was going.
Her hand goes to his collar. She adjusts his insignia. Sh smiles.
Where's your wing man? Who's  watching your six?
She breaks the spell abruptly, turns away.
Can I walk you out?She turns back to him, a smile.

From a car in the parking lot, we see Charlie and the Cap leave the club. They walk directly toward us and stop. Sh says something polite...a peck on the cheek. He turns awa dome light briefly illuminates the interior of the car as opens. It rocks slightly as someone gets in. Charlie turn and walks over, taking her keys out. She opens the door t car and gets in.
She starts the car and pulls away. Suddenly, a figure sit the back.
Startled, she nearly drives off the road. She turns to hi startled.
You! What are you doing here?
What if Captain Dawson had come  with me?
It would have been really  embarrassing!
How did you know this was my car?
Simple deduction. It's fast. It's  pretty. Sleek and stylish...It's  your color...matches your lipstick.
She pulls up at the guard gate, a MARINE CORPORAL is on d sees the pretty girl pull up and stop, leans over helpful
I don't know, Corporal. Can you do  anything about this lunatic?
The car door swings open. Maverick gets out. The car roar He stands in the glare of the spotlight...rocking on his looking across at the guard, who snaps to attention and s holes in his chest.
Two guys in flight suits run down stairs past stencils of kills on walls, then down corridor.
They skid to stop outside a door.
Ground crews work on planes in B.G. Jester in middle of l Door bursts open. Sundown and Flex skid to a halt when th whole class looking at them.
Flex...? You don't look like Flex   to me. You call that muscle?  Doesn't look like muscle. Looks  like...Pork.
They laugh. Even Sundown has to laugh, scratching his che
What're you laughing at? You're  Fungus.
Don't make an issue of it, it'll  stick.

Now to continue. In this class we  will be dealing with F-5's and  A4's, as our MiG simulators.  Technically the F-5 does not have  the thrust to weight ratio of the  MiG-21--it also does not bleed  energy below 300 knots like the  MiG-21 does. The A4 does not turn  as well as the MiG-17 but has  significantly better visibility.
Maverick looks back to his notes. SFX footsteps...door  opening. Viper looks up to back of room door.
Hi, Charlie. Good, our TAGREF's  here. Charlie's the most qualified  to get into P subs and curves, and  VN diagrams.
Maverick turns to see the TAGREF walk forward.  Maverick  stares at her as she passes without acknowledging him. He surprised, embarrassed.
Charlotte Blackwood--code name Charlie--  not your ordinary TAGREF. Charlie has  her Ph.D. in astrophysics--she's a  civilian contractor so you don't salute  her...or anything else. Is that clear?

She walks to the front and starts her presentation. She  talks about something very technical, arcane. MiG tactics technology. As the briefing rattles on, Maverick reacts t her. Goose glances over at him. He, too, recognizes the g He looks at his partner. Maverick feels his stare.

Hello, I think I have some new data for  you...Now a MiG 21 has a problem with  the inverted flight tanks. It won't do a  Negative G push over. Even below one G,  they risk a flame out. Operationally,  they will do a zero to one G only.
A snicker from the audience. She hesitates momentarily, g on. CHARLIE
The latest intelligence shows that  the most they will do in operation  is one....is there something wrong,  Lieutenant.
I don't think you're altogether  right...about the MiG, that is.
She stops--some of the pilots look at him. Viper glares.
No, I beg yours. But I don't think  you're right on that.
I saw a MiG do a 4 G negative dive.
(She doesn't believe him) Where did you see that?
Nervous buzz in the room. Viper goes rigid. Charlie can't believe it.
It's classified. Like Hollywood  says, I could tell you, but then  I'd have to kill you.
Pork stifles a laugh, the others chuckle. Viper is  embarrassed.
She stops Viper with a glance.
She can handle it. She is very cool, not overbearing. She says it calmly. She doesn't want to embarrass him any mor than he is, but she has to get the facts straight.
Lieutenant, I have a top secret  clearance. The Pentagon sees to it  that I know more than you.
(Flatly.) You saw a MiG push negative 4G?
He was in a 4G Negative dive and  you were on his six?
Yes, ma'am, At first. Then I was  directly above him.
She stares at him for a moment, then she has him. She goe for the kill.
If you were directly above him, how  did you see him?
A real buzz in the room.  Ice laughs audibly.
You were in a 4G inverted dive with  a MiG 21?   (She can't believe it.)
Chuckles, barely suppressed. Goose pipes up to deflect  attention.
One and a half, actually. I got a  polaroid.
Open laughter. She thinks it's at her. She grows red.
He shows her, but she can handle this.
So you're the reason those SALT talks failed.
The room breaks into laughter. At him. Now he grows red.  Goose puts his hand on Maverick's arm, shakes his head as to say: "Let it go, pal, she got you".
She looks at Viper. He doesn't know whether to laugh or c He knows there's something here he doesn't control.
It's just like he says, sir.
She walks away. He runs up and stops her.
Why didn't you tell me you were a
She studies him coolly for a moment, like a specimen.
You let me make a fool of myself.
You seemed determined to do that  anyway.. Why didn't you tell me you  were a famous MiG insulter? MAVERICK
Would it have made a difference?
You know, I'm assigned to this  school. I see sixteen new hotshots  every eight weeks. Your attention  is flattering, but not really  productive. Why don't you keep your  mind on flying.
She reaches over and aligns his collar insignia.
Why can't you keep this straight?
She smiles at him and walks away. Maverick turns, sees th others sizing him up. Most of them grin. Maverick moves d the corridor past the CO's Office. Viper leans against th
doorsill. He lights a pipe, laconically eyes Maverick. Hi tone gives away nothing, like an ELINT probe eliciting a  response.
Maverick... Where'd you get that  call sign?
Ahhh... Runs in the family, sir.
Maverick watches him for a beat, he's been tested, but he not sure how or why. He turns to catch up with Goose and others.
At twenty-eight thousand feet, the two planes circle each other, going in opposite directions. As they jockey for  position, they snap past each other like ends of bullwhip
The earth spins, the horizon appears and disappears. With each hard turn, Maverick and Goose can be heard "grunting keep blood in their brains, to keep from passing out.

The fight is hard, physical, and exhausting. The extreme forces--6.5--flatten them against their seats, causing th heads to weigh over one hundred pounds. Maverick strains turn his head and track the other jet as it streaks past Mach One.  MAVERICK
I've lost him -- where is he?
On your six -- coming hard. Four  hundred. Losing airspeed! He's on  your six and closing fast! Hard left! HARD LEFT!
Maverick jerks the stick left, and the F-14 takes an  astonishing turn. Jester ROARS past into a wide arc.
Take it down. Let's bug out of  here. Call for a draw.
No way. I'll nail him this time.  Going vertical.

THE PLANE EXPLODES INTO AFTERBURNER - rocketing toward  space. Jester is left in direct line with the sun, and hi canopy is sprayed with a blinding glare. Going ballistic dangerous. The plane flys like a bullet, obeying the laws physics, not the pilot's touch on control surfaces. The  ballistic call warns other aircraft that he is, for the  moment, out of control.
He's out of energy! You got  control? Unload!

The F-14 peels over the egg, in a backward dive. It rocke down the outside, gaining energy. Over the ROAR of jets, SCREAM of the wind, Goose shouts data, but it is muffled, distant voice in a typhoon. Through the canopy, we see  Jester, and he hangs in the air like a sparrow in the pat a falcon.
PILOT'S POV - HUD in windscreen - a diamond in a box.  Maverick lines up the diamond with Jester, and we hear th high pitched tone BEEPING.

head_text.subj: WE'RE BELOW THE HARD DECK. FIGHT'S

text: He's right. We're at ten thousand.
No way. I got you, sucker. You're  going down.
Jester maneuvers, but Maverick keeps him in the gunsight. The BEEPING is louder, faster.
In the envelope. FOX TWO MISSILE
There is an edge of anger in Jester's voice.

head_text.subj: ROGER FOX TWO. GET YOUR BUTTS ABOVE
THE HARD DECK. RETURN TO BASE

text: They are brought up short for a moment, then the thrill o victory gets the best of them. Goose lets out a war whoop The F-14 sweeps up, rolls into an Immelman..
Look, Ma, top of the world!
Maverick's Tomcat breaks hard and high, rolls over on its side, wings perpendicular to the ground. Goose sees the w go sideways.
Ahhh...A little high on the left,  don't you think?
He aileron rolls another quarter turn. Inverted, they pas right down the runway.  Goose looks out and insouciantly  watches the world go by at 300 knots, upside down.
Right. Much better. ...Ahhh...what  do you call this?
I wouldn't call it victory.  It's  more like...self immolation.

Controllers work. Officers watch the landing activity. On old salt, turns from the coffee machine, a cup of steamin Java microns from his lips. A ROAR. VABOOM! The Tomcat ro over. He yelps as hot coffee flys all over his shirt.
They complete the roll, bank left, zoom right by the towe level with the observation window.
52D.  F-14'S POV. Controllers look out at the F-14, mouth drop open.
Hi...Hi there. How ya doing in  there?  Mav... Ahhh...you know, at  one point I did want a Navy career.
You see all those guys with gold on  their shoulders!!?... Oh, no, I  think that was Johnson, Air Boss of  the Kitty Hawk!
Come on, we beat an instructor. How  many times in your life do you get  to do a victory roll?
Just once, if they take your plane  away.
They roll out, break over the runway.
Maverick and Goose walk by parking Tomcats...Ice is  unstrapping, Slider is climbing down. Ice looks at Maveri says one word.
Nice. Always a good idea to show up  your instructors. He nods toward Jester, glaring at them from his A4. Goose indicates the backseat of the Tomcat.
Hey, see any controls back there?  (thinks about team loyalty,  reacts to Jester's glare...) And anyway...we beat the Son of a  Bitch!
He turns and runs to catch up with Maverick.

Pilots half undressed. Maverick and Goose enter the room, carrying their helmets. The students look up at them, and Goose suddenly flashes a thumb's up sign with a grin. The students react with clenched fists, ad libs, high fives,  victory punches.
Thirty seconds. That's all it took  to blow us out of the sky.
We went like this, he went like  that. I say to Hollywood: Where'd  he go? Hollywood says: where'd who  go?
And he's laughing. Right over the  radio, He's laughing at us.

Attention turns to the doorway as Ice and Slider enter. I gives a brief dramatic pause, then flashes thumbs up and  smiles. The students celebrate Ice's win.  Ice handles th attention with the easy composure of one who is used to i Maverick ignores him and begins to peel out of his G-suit Ice moves toward his locker.
You won.  Congratulations.                HOLLYWOOD Maverick and Goose won too.
We won!  Ice turns back, stares them down, then turns back into hi locker, dismissing them.
Below the hard deck doesn't count.  You guys are the second team,  aren't you?
Maverick gets up, moves to him, starts to say something,  when Jester, breaks into the room.
SCREAMING AND YELLING.  A lot of screaming and yelling,  muffled by the door.
Enlisted Yeomen and Chiefs go about their clerical duties acute embarrassment mixed with curiousity. Behind the CO' someone is screaming his head off.

BOOM! The door bursts open. A big, brawling Officer - Joh the Air Boss - blasts out, nearly smashing into a female officer. She almost spills her coffee. Johnson looks righ left in fury too strong for words. He looks like he wants smash something. They move out of his way, but he justs b through the door and disappears down the hall. The enlisted men turn to Viper's office.

Jester stands inside stonefaced. Maverick and Goose are  rigid. Viper...with excess calm deliberation, softly walk over, grasps the doornob. He glances in this direction. T glance is totally without expression, and even scarier fo that.
In a flash, each man finds something totally engrossing i his work, or something terribly important to do elsewhere Slowly, steadily, Viper swings his door closed.54.  INT.

He moves over to face Maverick. There is a SILENCE like  after a train wreck; nothing but the POPPING of sprung me and the low GASP of escaping steam. Viper speaks quietly, like a funeral director consoling the living. Makes you w to scream.
Jester almost breaks into a grin.
Now...in addition...you broke two  major rules of engagement. And...  That's ...not good.
Maverick gives no response. Viper continues.
Lieutenant Candela lost sight of  you, and called "no joy". You  failed to respond.
He stops and looks at Maverick... A beat. Maverick finall nods  VIPER
Maverick is exhausted. It's been a long, rough day. His  voice is a horse whisper.
I had him in view. I was peeling  over the egg, into a dive. He saw  me when I moved in for the kill.  There wasn't any danger...
(to Goose) Is that how you remember it?
Yes, sir. By the time we could  respond, we were diving right into  his view.
Viper is not satisfied with the answer, but he moves on.
The hard deck for this hop was ten  thousand feet. Jester, at what  point did you call off the fight?
We weren't below for more than ten  seconds. There was no danger. I had  the shot. I took it.
The rules of engagement are not  flexible. They exist for your   safety. You will obey them. Is that clear?
Maverick thinks about continuing the discussion, but the  thought is momentary. He quickly cuts his losses, gives V what he thinks he wants...He is just on the cusp of too  sincere.
Yes sir, perfectly clear. I guess  we were ...I was... just a little  over enthusiastic.
Viper measures him for a moment, then lets it go.
Maverick and Goose leave the room. Viper looks at Jester, picks up Maverick's fitness report. Doesn't read it, look back at Jester.
I don't know what to tell you,  Skip.
...If you had to go into combat,  would you want him with you?

Jester turns, walks slowly around the room. The walls are lined with pictures; planes and pilots...history. There a MiG killers, attack squadrons, ground personnel...There's picture of a Phantom in flight with the backseater moonin the camera. Other pictures show carriers, famous flyers,  previous CO's. Finally Jester replys.
Viper slaps shut the fitness report.
He's seat of the pants...  Completely unpredictable -- nothing  by the book. All over the sky. But  I don't know, Skip, he's really got  something.
Yeah, we get one of these guys  every damn class.  (laughs)  "Maverick!"
He throws the report on the desk.
Wind ROAR, jet WHINE. Hollywood and Wolfman are being thr about as Hollywood fights the stick.
No. No. Look out, you lost it.
They depart flight. Tumble. The horizon swings wildly as  they go into flat spin.
A face appears at 12,000 feet, right in front of their  canopy. Goose's eyes bug at them.
Man, you guys gooned it. Your laser  butts are scattered across KANSAS.
(disgusted with himself) Come on. I died enough for one  night.
They climb out of the simulator - A cockpit sprung on  moveable rams, surrounded by a dome on which video images projected.
As they climb down, Maverick and Goose climb up into the  cockpit to take their place.
Have you guys ever considered  career counseling?
56B. SIMULATOR CONTROL ROOM - Filled with computers, tape transports and video screen representations of computer  generated combat. Now Maverick flies it as Charlie and ot techs watch.

Maverick flys the heck out of it. It's real. It lurches a bumps, the NOISES and sights look real. He gets on the ta of a MiG. It breaks, he breaks, then what he does is just fast to follow. It screams around in a turn. Suddenly, th is a WHUMMP...ALARMS...the lights come on.
What did you do in there?
What did you do? You broke it!
Maverick and Goose enter. The techs cluster around the  keyboards trying to reprogram, to figure out what went wr
You flew it off the template.  Nobody ever did that before.
That's what she said last night.
She stares at Goose until he grins and moves off to give others his valuable opinions on how to reprogram the  computers.
He just shrugs at her and smiles.
What would you say, too fast...too  quick...
It is combat. Every second counts.

The hottest moves in the world  aren't gonna help you if you wind  up alone.  Your wingman's got to be  able to follow you. Trust you. Know  that he can depend on you. It's  more than just fancy flying.
Well, what you need...what you have  to keep looking for...what you want  to get is a wingman who can stay up  with you. Who can match you move  for move. Then you've got  something.  I'm sorry.
That stuff about the MiG. I was out  of line.
There you go with those moves  again.
I don't mix with the boys. I work  here. Let's keep it professional.
Give me a break, I'm asking you  out.
I thought there was something...  That night in the club...
Maverick...you know the rules of  engagement.
Some one comes up hot on your six,  what do you do?
You turn into him, check him out,  identify friend or foe.
And if he's harmless, you  disengage.
You have to shoot him down....If  he's smart, he'll turn away before  that happens.
Harmless. Nobody ever called me  harmless before...
And probably never again. It's  nothing personal. It's just...I  know a lot of pilots. Maybe I'm  immune...
Don't worry, I'm a new strain. And  I don't give up. Everything I've  ever wanted I've had to work like  hell for. Well, how about it?
How about anything, anything you  want to do.
Hard to argue with that, isn't  it...
A date... Coffee... A drink...A  walk in the park.
Most of them invite me to sit in  the cockpit...play with the levers  and things.  MAVERICK
I'm starting to sense that now.
You're slow to engage. But you'll  come around.
She pushes him out the door
Okay, anything. Just...go. I've  gotta work.
She closes the door, turns back to her screen.

A day off. Pilots, other personnel are enjoying a day at beach. There are bikinis, and beer, sunfishes and water  skiing. The annual Over-the-Line (a variation of softball tournament is in progress. The team from the Teddy Kenned Driving School is whipping another known as Scum de Terre The pilots are doing pretty well at blowing off steam.
Undulating sea grass. Muffled HISS of the surf. A pretty  fish comes into view. A spear shoots through it, and nail to the ocean floor.
Two figures pop to the surface and wade in to the beach.  Maverick holds the wriggling fish. Charlie is repulsed. S pulls off her mask and snorkle, follows him in to shore..
They flop down. He drops the fish in front of her, sees h reaction at watching its death throes.
She looks at him for a moment, then turns away, fiddles w her mask.
I don't enjoy watching things  suffer.
He smashes the fish on a rock. It is still.
(she looks at him strangely,   half jokes) You're horrible
You're not, cause you eat frozen  meatballs?   (he puts it down) Things die. Every time you breathe,  you kill millions of tiny  organisms. Every time you eat,  something had to die.
You don't have to kill it.
Somebody does. It's more honest  this way. You do your own dirty  work.
You ever think about killing  another human being?
About as much as they think about  killing me.

They know the rules...(this is too  strong for her, she turns away, he  comes around to her.) That's the  deal. That's why you're up there.  It's him or me. That's the price of  admission. (she draws away) It  bothers you, why? You're part of  it. (She stiffens, he's losing her.  He softens)  Everybody dies. Most  people don't get to die for  something.
You don't want to confront it, do  you. You want to keep it all clean,  cerebral... velocity vectors,  wing-load diagrams...You ever been  up?
You use your mind to keep things at  a distance. You ever just let go?
You know what really scares me?  Living too long. Losing my hair and  my teeth...and my guts and my wind.  And my brains...Sitting in a room  with my hands in my lap, watching  daytime TV.
You don't believe any of this. You  don't think you'll ever die.
That's it, of course. When I'm up  there and doing it, I'm cheating it  every second. I'm subverting all  laws...gravity...whatever. I'm  skating the edge of it.
What he said..."There's nothing so  exhilarating as being shot at  without result."

All you've got is one life. I guess  it's worth about the same to every  body. You ever see an old woman  after her husband has died? And the  meaningless years of decline  stretch ahead...  When you're in  the air and doing something really  dangerous, you can look ahead...  maybe ten seconds. That's your  whole future. That's as far as it  goes. But imagine what those  seconds are worth.
What if you kill yourself? Think of  everything you'll miss. MAVERICK
There is lots of stuff I don't know  about...  Fine wine... great art...  the opera. I guess if I live long  enough, I'll get to it. If I don't,  I'll never miss it.

(shakes his head no.) I watched my mother die. Cancer.  She had a long time to think about  it. They say you reach an agreement  with death. Come to accept the fact  that pretty soon you won't be here.  I didn't see that. She... was very  brave...braver than I am. You go up  there, there isn't time to think.  If you make a mistake, you're just  a smudge on the ground. Simplifies  funeral arrangements.
(he smiles) Thanks very much. (he lifts the fish) Care for some suchi?.

head_text.subj: 59E. THE OTHER END OF THE BEACH

text: A killer volleyball game in progress. Maverick and Charli wander toward it, talking softly to themselves. Goose run and grabs him away.
Come on, I got over six bucks on  the line.

Maverick looks up and sees the other two-man team, the  victors, waiting on the other side of the net for them. O course it had to be Ice and Slider.Charlie sits and watch as the game gets immediately out of hand. In moments,  Maverick and Ice rotate to forward positions directly  opposite each other across the net. Other revelers turn t watch as it degenerates (?) to more than a game. Maverick glances at Charlie. He seems uncomfortable, but irrevocab drawn into the confrontation. She says nothing, but her  attitude is apparent. Back to the game: Slider and Goose them up, as they try to spike the ball in each other's fa The final point...up over the middle. They both go up,  Maverick smashes, Ice blocks, but the ball sails away, of his forearm. For the first time ever, Maverick beats him. looks over at Charlie, she is staring out to sea. She loo back at him and he's suddenly had enough competition. The call for another game, but Maverick turns away...
Come on, come on! It's double or  nothing.. We're talking twelve  bucks American, here.
He grabs Charlie and his gear..
I don't know. I don't like being  out of control.
He looks back at Ice, bouncing the ball and staring at hi
Stick with me, you'll get used to it.
The Bike doing 130, 140, 150 mph. Charlie is unfazed. He  turns to check her out, she smiles back at him.
The bike is parked in front.
MONTAGE ON LOCKED OFF CAMERA - to show the passage of tim latticed terrace, streaks of light. Maverick is feeding a Charlie sits on a rail watching him.
I always wanted to fly... ever  since I first saw a jet. I wanted  to fly jets, then I wanted F-14's,  then I wanted to fly off carriers,  then I wanted Top Gun.
You always get what you want?
He puts money in jukebox. She watches him...eye to eye  contact. The music comes on.
No fooling on base, no signs, no comments, no talk. By anyone.
I'm a professional. You guys are in my line of work.
A long beat. He looks at her -- makes the pact: like a  sailor.
She looks at his eyes for any sign of a put-on, insinceri Finally he smiles at her but she can read it. It's time. moves in and covers his grin with a gentle kiss.
To them sitting within striking distance at a table. The sleeps beneath. Their eyes are now locked. The electricit almost arcs between them.
TCU Scrub pine table. Their fingertips touch.
TIGHT SHOT. Waist to head. Holding, close together, swayi in time with the music. Their lips gently brush.
An F-14 swoops over the desert, ROARS over an antenna  complex.
The JET.- In it's missile rack, it carries a TACTS  transponder. The TACTS Range is an area of the desert  completely enveloped by computerized radar. The computers

calculate a number of aircraft's positions and velocities means of transponders in the ships and ground stations th talk to each other thousands of times a second.  Using th system, it is possible to track aerial combat instantaneo and give pilots directions and also to play back the comb for analysis.

The double viewing screens are five feet high; high  technology, state of the art. On the screens are computer animated figures showing jets from various angles. Flight data is displayed. The operators punch buttons to show  various points-of-view of the battle: a pilot's p.o.v.; G p.o.v. from overhead, a long range p.o.v., showing topogr of the landscape and height of mountains.
Students and instructors sit on chairs in the peanut  gallery, facing Viper at the front of the room. Charlie i the back.

The bandit has good position right  here. All right, freeze here. The  moment of choice -- Maverick is  defensive. He has a chance to bug  out right here....Better to retire  and save your plane than force a  bad position. Stay in the diamond  another three seconds, the bandit  will blow you out of the sky...make  a hard right, select zone  5...(turns to Maverick to drive  point home) you can extend and  escape. You make a bad choice. Roll  forward.
The computerized rendering resumes on the screen. VIPER (Con't)
You perform a split S. That's the  last thing you should do. The  bandit is right on your tail --  Freeze there...the bandit has you  in his gunsight. What were you  thinking here, Maverick?
I wasn't thinking. I just did it.
Big gamble with a thirty million  dollar plane!
It's a joke. Viper doesn't like that answer at all, but s of the students laugh and mockingly whistle at the cockin of it. They give Maverick the high sign. Slider leans for to him. SLIDER
Maverick slumps down in his chair under Viper's glare.  T computer rendering rolls forward again. He glances back a Charlie. She smiles sympathetically at him.

Unfortunately, the gamble worked,  or you might have learned  something. The bandit never gets a  clean shot...Maverick makes an  aggressive vertical move here,  comes over the top and defeats the  bandit with a missile shot. The  encounter was a victory, but we've  shown it as an example of what not  to do. Ice is next.
Another computerized rendering comes up on the screen.  Hollywood leans close to Maverick and speaks quietly.
Maverick gives him a small nod of appreciation.

And the dumbest...Okay, look at  this. It's textbook. Ice takes  control of the battle immediately.  He never gives the bandit a chance  to take the offensive. An early  turn here -- excellent. He goes for  the jugular, and it's over just  that quick. Let's run that again,  it's exactly how it should be done.
In full flight gear, carrying their helmets and trying to stuff food down their gullets, the students rush/stumble  toward the flight line. Hollywood takes a bit of a sandwi and makes a face. GOOSE
Don't chew it, you won't have it  that long. Easier to clean the  cockpit if it comes up in big  chunks.
On the run. Let's go. Move it!
A fighter pilot's lunch... a hot  dog and a puke.
They scurry ahead, overtaking the others.
I was a victim of circumstance.
They should have warned you about  that one.
She's kinky for flight suits--said  that she'd never seen so many  zippers--played with them all  night. The noise alone kept me up.
It's kind of ironic. All you guys  have women troubles and I don't.
That's because you don't have any  women.
Until last night. Did you see the  moves I was making on that girl at  the party?
The girl with the purple  fingernails?
That's her--tall hungry woman with  fire in her eyes. It was great.
The girl with the purple  fingernails was Coogan's sister.
They all laugh. Wolfman looks stunned.
Coogan spent half the night looking  for her. He said he was gonna kill  the son-of-a-bitch who ruined his  sister.
No, really. She came ruined!...    Ya think he knows it was me?
Seemed not to. But it's hard to  know. You never can tell what's in  the mind of a psychopath.

Wolfman looks very apprehensive as they approach the F-14 MECHANICS surround both planes, making last minute checks all systems. Among them is COOGAN, six and a half feet ta looking mean. Maverick tosses him a wave.
You guys know somethin' about that?
Wolfman swallows hard and hurries quickly into the plane. Coogan glares at them all with a look that could kill.

Hollywood leads, Maverick follows. They point their noses down and dive. Two bogies fly side by side at five thousa outlined against the blue Pacific. Smaller, slower, they helpless for a moment. We hear the instructors in the F-5
Keep your shirt on, he's saying  holy shit it's us.
The bogies split. Bogey One hard left. Bogey Two hard rig Hollywood sweeps left, pursuing Bogey One. Maverick hangs back to cover him.
Bogey One makes a strong vertical move. Hollywood stays o him. MAVERICK

head_text.subj: STAY WITH HIM, WOOD... YOUR SIX

text: Bogey One loops and comes down, and Hollywood almost lose him for a moment before regaining the angle.
Bogey at three o'clock high! Nose  on!
Maverick looks quickly at three o'clock high, sees Bogey returning to the fight. He jerks the stick right, and the planes make a quick pass.
Just cover Wood, Maverick. Mutual support, man!
Don't be greedy. Stay with Wood.
Maverick goes suddenly vertical, zooms straight up.

Maverick loops the F-14 down to get the quick angle on Vi in Bogey Two. Viper takes off, running from the fight aga Maverick looks over his shoulder and sees that Hollywood  still has a good position on Bogey One. He takes a hard r and streaks off after Viper.
What what are you doing? We're cover!
Goose looks back at Hollywood and Bogey One.

Viper streaks across the sky with Maverick close behind. pushes the throttle forward to ZONE 5 - full afterburner. Viper shows all his tricks...hard left, hard right, rolli into vertical, flipping into a dive. Maverick stays with
Maverick turns to get Viper in the diamond. He hears a  SIDEWINDER GROWL in his headset.
What's the range, Goose. I've got a  good tone.
Viper jinks but Maverick stays with him.  Viper is in the diamond, and the TONE GOES CRAZY. But suddenly....
Two bogies ! Three o'clock high,  nine o'clock high! Break!
They come out of nowhere, flashing down toward Maverick-- crossfire ambush. Maverick's eyes are startled.

head_text.subj: ATOLL ON THE NORTHERN F-14. HE'S

text: Maverick is stunned. He has been tricked, humiliated.  There's a little salt for the wound as Viper and Jester  celebrate.

head_text.subj: NOT ONLY THAT, BUT ZORRO GOT YOUR
INFORM YOU THAT YOUR SONS ARE DEAD

text: Slaps his helmet like a dolt...

head_text.subj: KNOCK OFF THE CHATTER, TOP GUNS.
LET'S RTB. VIPER HAS THE LEAD.

text: Silence. Several pilots in various forms of undress.  Maverick and Goose sit with their heads down, a hangdog  expression on their faces.
Maverick mopes at the bar, a figure comes up behind him.
Ya know, that was the best flying  I've seen since Nam...(He grins)  ...Right up to that part where you  got killed.
Viper sits down. He's in a jovial, taunting mood.  Maveri watches him guardedly.
Twenty years' experience, I  couldn't shake you. You may be a  great flyer. I mean that.

Of course you did. I said a great  flyer, not a smart one. You fly  reckless. Great instincts. No  discipline. That ambush today, you  followed your emotions instead of  your wingman. Of course you got  killed...and well deserved to. It  was a really stupid mistake. In  battle, it gets people killed.
Maverick nods and stares at his beer.
I can take care of myself.

Talent is no holy shield. Von  Richtofen was killed by a farm boy.  Instincts are not enough. Do it our  way. We've worked these things out.  The good pilots can become better  and the great ones can learn how to  stay alive.  (he studies him for a  moment)  Why do you have to do  everything the hard way?
It's my own way. It works for me.   I don't care about the rest of that  stuff.
For the same reason you are.
The flying. The fighting.  I'd go  up there ten times a day to fight.  I'd win at least nine of them.  That's all I want to do. It's what  I do best. I am real good.  Just  give me the jet.
It's not a gift, just a loan...
He finishes his beer, then rises.

Nine out of ten is okay, as long as  it's only fun and games. But this  isn't about that. This is serious  business. It is dangerous up there!  At 500 knots, things can change a  lot in a second. Discipline is what  protects us.
He signals the bartender and drops some money on the bar. stretches, looks around.

It was a good day. You learned  something. You lost and you're  still alive to think about it. And,  you lost your wingman. That's a  cardinal sin...don't ever do it  again. You owe Hollywood an apology  and you owe me a beer.
Viper touches Maverick's shoulder as he moves away. It wa just the gesture Maverick needed, for he seems to relax f his tension. He sips his beer alone.
Maverick and Goose move through the terminal,  anxious/expectant looks on their faces.
Relationships are a bitch, here.  It's hard enough to concentrate  ...under the pressure. Having a  woman here is asking for it.
I guess that's what I'm doing,  then.
Where do you find the time? Where  do you find the energy. It's tough  enough to keep your mind on school.  A woman here is a real pain in  the...

A pretty woman emerges from the crowd and spots them firs She rushes them, happily, carrying her sleepy four-year-o RICKY. Goose undergoes an immediate change, beaming a big smile that he has practiced on her for years. She sets do the kid.
...butt...Hi, honey, God, am I glad  to see you! I missed you.
Goose wraps his arms around Carol, smack, a kiss. She smi at Maverick, turns back to Goose.
I had to come, Willard, I got so  lonesome I just couldn't stand it.
Sure, honey, I understand. It's  great to see you. Hey where's your  backseater, where's the world's  smallest RIO..

He looks all around and then down at the kid, hiding shyl behind his mother's skirts. Goose grabs up the kid and zo him around, a game they've played before, every six month so. The kid laughs happily.  Maverick just sort of smiles himself and shakes his head.
Maverick comes to the surface. She enters frame by the si of the pool.  She hands him a split fresh pineapple. He e it in the  most salacious manner possible. He's so conten he's babbling.
You ever fly an F-14? (She laughs.)
I don't fly in anything that doesn't show movies.
He gets out, grabs a towel, moves over to some chairs. Hi flight suit is draped over one. He moves it to sit down.

Ahhh, you'd love it. Night carrier  landings! The most dangerous thing  you can think of! ...next to  you...And the most exciting. You're  living at one hundred and ten per  cent. Greatest high in the world...

His flight suit slips onto the ground. Charlie retrieves As she lifts the suit, something falls out of the pocket. Looks like a gold coin. She picks it up. Maverick is dryi his hair. She holds the object out to him, questioning. H sees it, quickly takes it, stuffs it back into his pocket
What do you take me for? It's a  Navy Cross.
He roots through a picnic basket.

...MiG sweep over the water.  You  will proceed down the one-seven  -zero degree radial looking for  MiGs. You will engage all that you  find, destroy them, and return to  base. Maverick, has the lead. Any  questions? All right, let's go.  Move like you've got a  purpose....
Four F-14's fly in formation over the Pacific, searching (MiGs). They spot them, engage. The combatants fly scisso patterns, slashing past each other, angling for position.

We hear the VOICES OF COMBAT from the planes, a barrage o information exchanges between pilots and RIO's. Maverick Ice swoop close together on each other's wing--moving on other, testing, they glance at each other and nod. The  Challenge...the fight is on. Suddenly an F-5 rises up out the clouds in front of them--Ice has the advantage and ro in on him.
The F-5 sees his pursuers. Goes into a hard left.

head_text.subj: MIG'S IN A LEFT. MIG'S IN A

text: Ice struggles against the G's to bring his nose to bear.  They go around into a Lufbery--a tight circle, Ice has th advantage. He is closer to the F-5's tail than the F-5 is his. But he can't close, can't line up the shot. He grunt and strains as the G force pushes him down.

head_text.subj: STAY WHERE YOU ARE. HE'S MINE. I'M

text: Maverick maneuvers close to their left circle.

head_text.subj: GET OUT OF THERE, YOU'RE UNSAFE.
YOU GOT TOO MUCH NOSE TO TAIL
COME OFF--COME OFF RIGHT. I'M ON MY
WAY IN. YOU GO FREE, I'M ENGAGING.
STAY OUT OF IT. STAY OUT OF IT,
YOU CAN'T SHOOT HIM, I CAN. I'M IN.
ICE, ROLL OFF, I CAN SHOOT HIM.

text: Maverick is pulling a log of G's, but can't target his  weapons, he continues to turn in a hard circle, going rou and round without gaining. He can't bring his nose to bea

head_text.subj: IF YOU CAN'T SHOOT HIM, I CAN.
NO, I GOT HIM. I CAN TAKE HIM.

text: Maverick dives down between the two planes pulling 6.5 G' exposing his underside to Ice. All Ice sees is belly.  Obviously, in this attitude Maverick can't see him.
He slams the stick hard right in toward Maverick.  Ice quickly rolls up right, in front of him.
Maverick sees him flash into his view. He has to slam the stick forward to avoid collision. He swings by real close Too close.

They pass through Ice's turbulence. The blast distorts th airflow to Maverick's left engine. BOOMBOOMBOOM. The engi flames out. Full thrust on the right, engine swings the t around in a yaw. Maverick slams the stick right to correc but too late.
Plane's coupling up! Plane's  coupling up!
The plane couples one yaw to the next--the tail swings  around-- which becomes an ever increasing flat spin, like out-of -control frisbee.
This is not good!...(Rising panic)  We're low!
Maverick is pinned to the instrument panel by centrifugal force, desperately tries to reach back for the ejection  lever--but is falling short by about a foot.

The plane is spinning ever faster, out of control. He dro the gear. Still spins. Goose is closer to center of spin- forces are less. He reaches behind him for the eject hand starts the eject sequence.
Go ahead. I can't reach. 2000 feet!
The canopy BLASTS away--but is held spinning above the  cockpit by the vortex of the sinking jet. Goose glances u it.

Goose yanks the ejection handle. Things happen in a split second. Goose is fired up and out by the rocket under his seat. Almost instantly he impacts the spinning canopy. A  sickening CRUNCH. The canopy is knocked away. Maverick is slammed back in his seat as the ejection seat straps wind He is BLASTED out of the plane just before it spins in.

head_text.subj: 85B. TIGHT ON MAVERICK AS HE TUMBLES IN SLOW MOTION

text: He's in shock..the loud THUMPING of his heart, labored  breathing, a scream that stays in his mind.

Instinctively, he gropes for straps. He releases the pilo seat, it tumbles away. His chute streams, balloons open,  snapping his body like a bullwhip.  He drifts momentarily then plunges into the sea.
His face, distorted in the water; wild eyes, disoriented, choking for air. He reaches out, finds nothing to grab. Suddenly, he is yanked hard to the side.

The parachute is caught by the wind, and dragged, pulling Maverick along beneath the surface. He is twisting in the water, turning over and over, trying desperately to slip of the tangled straps. He finally hits the surface of the water and sucks air into his lungs. With the end of his  strength, he hits the release snaps and breaks free from parachute. It whips away like a kite in a typhoon.

The sea is choppy and rough. He struggles as his equipmen drags him under. He twists, finds the inflatable raft  attached to his harness. Maverick pulls the cord, and the raft hisses open. He pulls his body into the six-by-two f raft and collapses, completely exhausted. The survival ha been almost without thinking: an instinctual physical  struggle.

Maverick begins to focus on the situation. He stains the  water with dye, then sees another parachute floating near Paddling to the parachute, he reaches over the side and  begins to pull on the heavy cords that are submerged in t water.

A great struggle. The weight is extremely heavy. Finally, pulls a body to the surface. Goose. Goose is dead. Maveri releases the parachute and pulls Goose into the raft on t of him. He holds Goose in his arms. His mind shuts down  again.
From high above the ocean, we see the debris on the water An oil slick, pieces of honeycomb titanium, and the small helpless figure in the raft.

Searchlights skim over the black ocean. A brilliant light flashes as Maverick pops a pencil flare. Helicopter blade flick powerfully. The lights of the choppers descend towa the wreckage area, scanning the debris, searching for lif The spotlights find Maverick and Goose in the raft.
The draft from the chopper churns the water. A FROGMAN dr from the chopper and hits with a heavy splashes. He surfa and swims to the raft as a rescue harness is lowered.
Maverick watches curiously as he starts to examine Goose. hugs Goose closer and looks threatened.
Let him go, sir. Take it easy.
He tries to pry Goose free, but Maverick has a death grip the body.
Sir! Let him go. It's all right.  Let him go.
Maverick glares at the man as he bobs in the water.
Another long moment, then Maverick releases Goose. The  frogman quickly straps Maverick into the harness.
HIS POV. - He watches the lifeless body in the water as h is pulled up and away. He shivers from the cold.
Extreme CLOSE ON Maverick's face. He is emotionless. His  eyes are flat and absolutely without expression. There is complete silence in the room. Then we hear the quiet, cal probing voice of Viper.
Not one sign of emotion from Maverick. Not one tone of  expression. We see Viper now, and his face is strained fr very long day.
If you fly jets long enough,  something like this happens to you.  No one escapes it. It touches us  all.
Maverick looks at Viper, and his eyes are very disturbed.
My first squadron in Vietnam, we  lost eight out of eighteen planes.  Ten guys. The first one kills you,  but there'll be others--you can  count on it.
No reaction from Maverick. He can't quite face up to that reality right now.
You've got to put him in the box.
Maverick is watching Viper, but he doesn't have anything say.
The RADIO plays John Lennon; "Stand by Me". Maverick open his eyes, doesn't know where he is for a moment.
The dark side. The price you pay  for all the fun you're having. You  knew about it, of course. Didn't  you?
He was a friend of mine. A good  guy...great guy. It was my  fault.
That's what you get flight pay for.
(In surprise) Why? You act like you didn't know  one day this would happen.
You knew it. You all do. It's part  of it. Maybe the most important  part.
Charlie's car pulls up. They get out and walk down toward the water. Maverick seems dazed. She is softly taunting.
Where are we? You know where we  are. It's called the beach. It's  where life first crawled up out of  the sea. I come here sometimes...  when I feel like crawling back in.
You don't have to do this.
Do what, show you a good time?
I'm not good company. I should be  alone.
I don't think so, but if that's  what you want...
They stand there, not making a move.
She turns, nods out, past the moon.
You look way out there. Out past  the date line. West becomes East,  all things change. You cross the  line...today becomes yesterday...or  tomorrow, I forget which.
Of course the line's just  imaginary. You can cross it twenty  times...nothing really changes.
She turns and walks along the surfline.

On the beach... It's what they say  when Navy men retire...He's "On The  Beach". I always liked that. I had  a picture...in my head... all these  old guys wandering around here,  looking out into the past.
He walks to the surf, kicks the sand with his bare feet.
If we knew then, what we know now,  we might never have come up out of  there.
He turns to her. She just looks at him.
Only when you're depressed. Then it  passes.
Everything passes. Immutable law of  the Universe.
He picks up a piece of flotsam, a twig, worn smooth.
This too...shall pass. You put as  much life as you can between it and  you. You start piling up experience  between then and now.
What do you do when you come here?
I sit. I think. I play games.
It's strip reality, actually, like  what the pilots always want to  play.
(this gets a small laugh) Strip reality! How do you play  that?

It's like strip poker, only,  without the bluffing. (he laughs  again) One person says something  and if the other one accepts that  it's true, the one who says it,  gets to take one item of clothing  off.
You're crazy. (She stops, he goes  on, softer) That's a pretty silly  game.
Not as silly as some. You know the  silliest one? ...that we are gods.  That we control events on the  beach... that we can turn back  time...
You say the truth. (a beat...)     Go ahead. Don't be afraid. You want  to win the game, don'tcha?
The big one. The one that's most on  your mind.
He takes the ribbon from her hair. It falls down over her face and shoulders. Now it's her turn.
He nods. She slowly loosens his tie and pulls it from aro his neck.
She says nothing, stands looking into his eyes. He slowly as if in a trance, takes her blouse off.
He starts to reach for her. She pulls back.
She turns and thinks for a moment, looking at the moon.
Rather than struggle his T shirt over his head, she grabs with both hands. She leans in close and bites it. She gra both sides of the tear and slowly rips it off his body.
(shakes her head no) That wasn't fair. It was a  question. Penalty round!
You didn't mean it. You didn't  think. You'd do anything to take it  back.
She unbuckles his belt, slowly slides it off. She unzips pants, they fall.
He rests his head on her shoulder, unhooks her bra. She  shrugs it off.
They stand on the beach in shorts and bikini bottom, look into each other's eyes.
We'll say it together. On the count  of three...One...two...
Leaning in, softer and harder...they both jump the gun.
They embrace madly and sink to the sand. From the distanc it looks like a strange slithering creature crawling back the sea.
The lights are out in Goose's room at the Bachelor Office Quarters. The door opens, and Maverick enters. He sets a  cardboard box on the bed.

Silently, Maverick gathers together Goose's few personal  possessions. He fills the box with clothes, books, a cloc radio, a walkman, and articles from the bathroom. He exam each closely, like an artifact...as if he might find some message or meaning in them. He fumbles them into the box. can't see too well, his eyes are full of tears.
Maverick closes the box and carries it to the door. He ta one last glance around, then leaves and closes the door  behind him.

Carol and the kid, stand, staring at a silent TV. Carol  looks dazed, lost. Maverick walks in, finds her. An awkwa silence while they both try to think of something to say. Maverick hands the box to Carol.
